message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including fever, rash, and blue-white spots on the oral mucosa, suggest a viral infection. Among the options, only ssRNA enveloped viruses, specifically the Paramyxoviridae family, can cause this set of symptoms. Measles virus, a member of this family, can cause the described symptoms and is highly contagious.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a maculopapular rash, blue-white spots on oral mucosa, and mild conjunctival injection indicates a diagnosis of Measles (Rubeola). Measles belongs to the ssRNA enveloped viruses family.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a maculopapular rash on the face, trunk, and proximal limbs, as well as blue-white spots on the oral mucosa and mild conjunctival injection, are all signs of measles infection. Measles belongs to the ssRNA enveloped viruses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms (fever, cough, rash, and blue-white spots on oral mucosa) suggest that the causative agent of this condition is measles, which belongs to the ssRNA enveloped viruses family.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the boy has measles, which is caused by a virus belonging to the ssRNA enveloped viruses family.
